>     only problem with testing queries like this is that your test will be time and
>     database dependent,


No because you typically work with an empty test database.  You then 
insert the data you will test.  Your data is not time dependant anymore. 
Remember that you are "unit" testing your application (i.e. testing that 
it does what it should do) and that your database can be in a 
non-dynamic state.

Database dependent: normally inserting data into a database if pretty 
simple but it's true that if you plan to support Sybase, Oracle and 
mySQL, you may have to write 3 different scripts to populate your 3 
different databases.  But it must be done only once.

>     There is a line of thought that all you need to do is make sure your SQL
>     is valid. beyond that you're testing your database, not your method...


It also depends what you mean with a "valid SQL statement".  Having a 
valid SQL statement and having a SQL statement that does what it has to 
do are two different things (or you never makes any mistake writing a 
complex SQL statement...).

If you have an object that can be saved, updated and retrieved from a 
database, a nice way to test your SQL statement and your database is to:

1. create an object with valid data
2. store the object into the database
3. retrieve from the database into another object
4. compare that these two objects are equal

You haven't directly test your database, but how your objects are 
saved/modified/retrieved from the database.  It will be easier to find 
problems when the database model changes.

-Vladimir
